body:
I think this a nice idea.

Unfortunately not all the cloud storage systems can stream data - they need to know the size in advance.

I think it would need a different internal interface probably, as the current upload interface needs the size.
What about the other way? I was searching for something like "rclone cat remote:path | xz -d > file" and came here.

@harrytuttle I just implemented an rclone cat command actually!  It will be in v1.33.

I think I need to solve the unknown size problem to make FUSE work properly so this ticket will probably be possible then (piping stuff to rclone for upload).
Ah, a commit 18 hour ago, i'd call that serendipity! And that fuse mount command sounds super slick for sure. Thanks!
Sorry if i have to bump this, but i dont get the rclone cat Command... It looks like he can only output data from the cloud, but not take output from my tar generated archive...

issue.title: New feature: "rcat" (inverse of cat) command for rclone

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

body: @RaymondSchnyder You'll want #1001 which is the `rcat` command coming in 1.37 with any luck!

issue.title: rclone: avoid temp files
issue.body:
The rclone store is the only part we need temp files for. The rest works with stdin+stdout.

Waiting for `rclone rcat`:
* https://github.com/ncw/rclone/issues/230
* https://github.com/ncw/rclone/issues/1001

Then get rid of all temp files-related code (unless adding a `pathcmd` proc: command proc that takes path(s) as input).

body:
I've put together a wrapper tool tonight that can support piping data into and out of an rclone destination. It's certainly alpha-level, so use at your own risk, and let me know how it works for you. I tested piping in a zfs send into and encrypted store, and later retrieving it to a zfs recv.

[https://github.com/eborisch/rpipe](url)

As you can read there:

```
Works by creating temporary files of size --chunksize in --tempdir, and
uploading those. By default runs two 'jobs', such that an upload can be
occuring while the next chunk is being built. As such, tempdir needs to
be able to hold two chunks. They are deleted and checksum-ed along the
way, and verified during retrieval.

Make sure that your destination doesn't exist (purge it first.) This will
likely be added as a default step on a future version.

Examples:
    <some source> | rpipe.py remote:some/empty/loc
    <some source> | rpipe.py --nocheck crypt:an/encrypted/loc
                    ^ As we can't check the md5s of the deposited files on an
                      encrypted store...
    rpipe.py --replay remote:some/empty/loc | <some sink>
    rpipe.py --replay --nocheck crypt:an/ecrypted/loc | <some sink>

```

issue.title: Upload file to remote storage from URL

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
Directly uploading to remote storage from a URL would be a useful feature, for example:

`rclone copy http:https://example.com/some_large_file.tar remote:/Files`

This would be useful for systems without enough free space to save the entire file before upload (for example a VPS).

I understand that currently `rclone` needs to know the size of the file before upload (https://github.com/ncw/rclone/issues/230#issuecomment-161762623), however properly configured webservers should send a [`Content-Length`](https://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec14.html#sec14.13) header which indicates the size of the file.

body: @ncw I don't see the `rcat` command in the master branch. Is it actually already committed?
Rcat isn't done yet - soon hopefully!
